articles.headline: Social Media Punished as Results Fall Short
articles.snippet: The performances illustrate the way investors are questioning whether social media companies can keep their growth rates vigorous enough to justify their valuations.
articles.abstract: The performances illustrate the way investors are questioning whether social media companies can keep their growth rates vigorous enough to justify their valuations.
articles.lead_paragraph: A trio of social media stocks is getting pummeled this week, a sign that Wall Street may be unwilling to overlook missteps at some of its Internet darlings.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Patriot Act Faces Revisions Backed by Both Parties
articles.snippet: The push for reform is the strongest demonstration of a shift from a focus on national security at the expense of civil liberties to a new balance in the post-Edward J. Snowden era.
articles.abstract: The push for reform is the strongest demonstration of a shift from a focus on national security at the expense of civil liberties to a new balance in the post-Edward J. Snowden era.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than a decade of wrenching national debate over the intrusiveness of government intelligence agencies, a bipartisan wave of support has gathered to sharply limit the federal government’s sweeps of phone and Internet records.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Crime, Clinton and a New Era
articles.snippet: As the streets of Baltimore erupt in protests, and questions about race, poverty and the prison population tower over the political landscape, the halcyon years of the tough-on-crime Bill Clinton administration look less idyllic.
articles.abstract: As the streets of Baltimore erupt in protests, and questions about race, poverty and the prison population tower over the political landscape, the halcyon years of the tough-on-crime Bill Clinton administration look less idyllic.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a favorite riposte of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s in her 2008 presidential campaign: “I always wonder what part of the 1990s they didn’t like,” she would say about critics who brought up her husband’s administration, “the peace or the prosperity?”

articles.headline: Commonly Used Chemicals Come Under New Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A class of chemicals that replaced an older group found to be harmful to health is now drawing criticism for the same reason.
articles.abstract: A class of chemicals that replaced an older group found to be harmful to health is now drawing criticism for the same reason.
articles.lead_paragraph: A top federal health official and hundreds of environmental scientists on Friday voiced new health concerns about a common class of chemicals used in products as varied as pizza boxes and carpet treatments.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: A Woman-Led Law Firm That Lets Partners Be Parents
articles.snippet: The Geller Law Group is determined to show that parents can nurture their professional ambitions while being fully present in their children’s lives.
articles.abstract: The Geller Law Group is determined to show that parents can nurture their professional ambitions while being fully present in their children’s lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just past 9:30 on a Wednesday morning in March, after she drove 20 minutes to drop her son, Jack, off at preschool, after she trekked back for an hour across the Washington metro area into Fairfax, Va., for work, and long, long after she answered her first email, Maria Simon sat in a windowless conference room weighing the odds that she would be able to make a party in Jack’s class two days hence.

articles.headline: Pine Ridge Indian Reservation Struggles With Suicides Among Its Young
articles.snippet: Since December, nine people between 12 and 24 years old have killed themselves on the South Dakota reservation, and many others have tried.
articles.abstract: Since December, nine people between 12 and 24 years old have killed themselves on the South Dakota reservation, and many others have tried.
articles.lead_paragraph: PINE RIDGE INDIAN RESERVATION, S.D. — A few days before Christmas, Santana Janis, a 12-year-old Lakota Indian, decided that she did not want to live anymore.

articles.headline: 6 Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death
articles.snippet: Prosecutors in Baltimore described repeated mistreatment of a 25-year-old man whose death has set the city on edge.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors in Baltimore described repeated mistreatment of a 25-year-old man whose death has set the city on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Baltimore’s chief prosecutor charged six police officers on Friday with a range of crimes including murder and manslaughter in the arrest and fatal injury of Freddie Gray, a striking and surprisingly swift turn in a case that has drawn national attention to police conduct.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Pension Funds Can Only Guess at Private Equity’s Cost
articles.snippet: One study estimated that more than half of what private equity charges pension funds to manage their investments is not being disclosed.
articles.abstract: One study estimated that more than half of what private equity charges pension funds to manage their investments is not being disclosed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Partnership agreements outlining private equity firms’ practices are as closely guarded as the recipe for Coca-Cola.

articles.headline: Student Loan Facts They Wish They Had Known
articles.snippet: Personal stories about student loans painted a picture of clueless teenagers, frazzled parents and college administrators who may not question students about their debt levels.
articles.abstract: Personal stories about student loans painted a picture of clueless teenagers, frazzled parents and college administrators who may not question students about their debt levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: The problem with a lot of the advice that teenagers and their families get about higher education debt is that it’s totally, utterly bloodless.

articles.headline: Marilyn Mosby, Prosecutor in Freddie Gray Case, Takes a Stand and Calms a Troubled City
articles.snippet: Ms. Mosby, who on Friday announced criminal charges against six police officers in Mr. Gray’s death, took office only four months ago, elected with the backing of community activists.
articles.abstract: Ms. Mosby, who on Friday announced criminal charges against six police officers in Mr. Gray’s death, took office only four months ago, elected with the backing of community activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Shortly before she became the youngest top prosecutor in any major American city, Marilyn J. Mosby, a daughter and granddaughter of police officers, had tough words about how the nation’s criminal justice system had handled mistreatment of black men by the police.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Mixed Verdicts in Second Trial of Aleynikov, Ex-Goldman Sachs Programmer
articles.snippet: A jury convicted Sergey Aleynikov on a charge of stealing confidential computer trading code from his former employer, but acquitted him of a second charge and deadlocked on a third.
articles.abstract: A jury convicted Sergey Aleynikov on a charge of stealing confidential computer trading code from his former employer, but acquitted him of a second charge and deadlocked on a third.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the second time in five years, prosecutors have prevailed over Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer accused of stealing confidential computer trading code from the bank. The first time it took a federal jury just hours to convict; this time it came after more than a week of deliberation and an accusation of “food poisoning” and avocado tampering in a state court jury room.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess
